data.text: Wrist Pain when Bikepacking

wrist pains - i have them, how to make them go away? i've started a bikepacking/touring trip and my wrists, especially my left wrist, are starting to hurt. i thought i got things right- i have a 22.5 degree OG on-one raised handlebar, ergon grips, padded gloves, played with the angles until it felt just right, even got a redshift stem for the bumps. but something doesn't sit right. i thought i was maybe too enthusiastic with the downhills and got hit too hard, but i'm not sure, as i still feel pain, especially when i use my left hand to press things (stuffing the sleeping bag, sending the thumb to change gears). maybe it's because i'm using 2 fingers on a single finger brake lever? it's not terribly painful, but i want to get this sort out before it does. anyone got any ideas?

which side of the wrist? Thumb side? top side? The way it looks in your video you keep extending the thumb. Perhaps your grip is a bit too far from the shifter? Do you contantly keep your thumb in that position, even without the need for shifting? keeping the thumb extended in its end range can cause a lot of stress to the tendon and the surrounding structures. what kind of pain? does it feel like something jammed? a muscle sore? an ache from deeper inside? a sharp pain, stabbing/lightning bolt? Honestly can't make a valid assessment without personally seeing you. But start with not extending the thumb when you don't need to.

data.text: What worked for me was a more upright seating position, taking calcium supplements, consciously relaxing my grip, and setting up the most natural hand position. I thought THAT hand position was palms facing the ground like you have here, until I realized how they were positioned while at my side. I rotated my riser handlebars until the thumb sides of my hands were about 20 degrees up. Good luck.

data.text: Sounds like it might be repetitive strain injury (RSI) or possibly carpal tunnel syndrome, which is correctable. Looking at your video, you appear to have your fingers constantly on, or hovering over the levers. If you do that most of the time then RSI is possible. Other than that, it could be you are putting too much shock/ load on your wrists. I had to teach myself (muscle memory) to ride head up, shoulders down, arms bent, elbows in, hands relaxed with a loose hold on the bars. It took many miles before I did that on autopilot. Sorry if I am teaching you how to suck eggs. As for treatment. Ibuprofen and tennis players wrist straps will help. If you can, take rest days too.

data.text: No matter what hand position(s) or grip or bars you utilize if your core is weak and you place too much of your weight on your hands you will have discomfort. Likely the best prevention will be to raise your handlebar by changing the stem with one that is shorter, taller or angled upward. This changes your upper body position resulting in less weight/pressure on your hands and wrists. Riding with bent elbows resulting in a more relaxed, shock absorbing arms will also help. Good luck.

data.text: Take the time to develop a stretching routine, and work every muscle group from head to toe at least once a week. The importance of this can't be emphasized enough, and you'll begin to see "miraculous" results throughout your overall physiology. Learn to observe good posture at all times as well, and of course having a bike that's the correct size and adjusted properly is crucial if you'll be spending prolonged hours in the saddle. The most notable improvements will be increased blood circulation to ALL parts of the body, and cavitation of bones that may be out of whack due to a lifetime of neglect. This is not an overnight process though and will require devotion, which can be a problem for anyone who wants their health handed to them on a silver platter with no effort as so many seem to think they're entitled to. "Float like a butterfly, sting like a bee". It's also important to be relaxed at all times if possible, because tension hinders our processes and causes more problems than we realize. Maybe at first just stretch the upper body focusing on the forearms, upper arms, shoulders, and head/neck to increase blood flow and nerve function to these areas?

data.text: There are 3 ways to adjust the drops to get a better fit. 1. You can loosen the screws on the stem and "roll" the whole handlebar up or down. 2. You can loosen the band on the hoods and move the hoods forwards or backward on the hoop. 3. The most important, and usually forgotten. You can loosen the band on the hoods and rotate them inwards or outwards (without moving up or down the bar). Dead straight is rarely the most comfortable for most people. Generally angled in a little suits most people, but it does vary. That goves you plenty to work with, without even adjusting height or the stemüòâ

data.text: Lots of good ideas here, but, there a lot of variables that could be contributing to your pain, and, what works for one, might not for another. Keeping your weight back and not supporting yourself too much with your hands is the most obvious fix. For me, changing hand positions, shaking out my hands intermittently, and favoring the hand-shake position (hoods for me, bar ends for you) has helped. Also, don‚Äôt overlook the benefits of taking regular breaks, and increasing their frequency as the day grinds on. Getting off the bike and shaking everything out can do wonders -
